--- title: "Introduction to ANOVA" author: "Dr. Joshua Lambert" output: html runtime: shiny format: html: toc: true toc-title: "Table of Contents" code-fold: true code-tools: true css: styles.css --- # Understanding Hypothesis Testing and ANOVA ### Constructing a Written and Mathematical Hypothesis When constructing a hypothesis for ANOVA, it's important to formulate it both in a written and mathematical format. - **Written Hypothesis (Example 1):** - Null Hypothesis (H₀): The average stress in cardiac patients is not different between a placebo group and a behavioral intervention group. - Alternative Hypothesis (H₁): The average stress in cardiac patients differs between the placebo and behavioral intervention groups. - **Mathematical Hypothesis (Example 1):**
Mathematical Example: 
  •           H₀: μ_p = μ_b
          H₁: μ_p ≠ μ_b
### T-test vs. ANOVA When comparing means between two groups, the t-test and ANOVA will yield the same results. However, ANOVA extends to cases with more than two groups. ### Writing ANOVA Hypothesis, Type 1 and 2 Errors In ANOVA, the hypotheses are: - Null Hypothesis (H₀): All group means are equal. - Alternative Hypothesis (H₁): At least one group mean is different. Type 1 Error: Rejecting the null hypothesis when it is true (false positive). Type 2 Error: Failing to reject the null hypothesis when it is false (false negative). ### Assumptions of ANOVA 1. The dependent variable is measured on an interval or ratio scale. 2. The independent variable is categorical. 3. Random sampling. 4. Normal distribution of the dependent variable. 5. Homogeneity of variance. ### Visualizing Using Boxplots Boxplots are essential for visualizing data distribution across groups in ANOVA.
JMP Instructions:
  • Go to Graph > Graph Builder.
  • Select your categorical variable for the x-axis and your continuous variable for the y-axis.
  • Click Box Plot in the ribbon to display.
  • Click Done to finalize.
R Code Example: 
  •         # Example boxplot in R
        data <- data.frame(
          group = rep(c("Placebo", "Behavioral", "Drug"), each = 10),
          stress = c(rnorm(10, 5, 1), rnorm(10, 7, 1), rnorm(10, 6, 1))
        )
        boxplot(stress ~ group, data = data, main = "Boxplot of Stress Scores",
                xlab = "Group", ylab = "Stress Score")
Python Code Example: 
  •         # Example boxplot in Python
        import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
        import seaborn as sns
        import pandas as pd
        import numpy as np

        # Generate data
        data = pd.DataFrame({
          "group": np.repeat(["Placebo", "Behavioral", "Drug"], 10),
          "stress": np.concatenate([np.random.normal(5, 1, 10),
                                    np.random.normal(7, 1, 10),
                                    np.random.normal(6, 1, 10)])
        })

        # Boxplot
        sns.boxplot(x="group", y="stress", data=data)
        plt.title("Boxplot of Stress Scores")
        plt.xlabel("Group")
        plt.ylabel("Stress Score")
        plt.show()
SPSS Instructions:
  • Go to Analyze > Descriptive Statistics > Explore.
  • Select your categorical variable as the factor and continuous variable as the dependent list.
  • Click Plots, check Boxplots, and click Continue.
  • Click OK to generate the boxplot.
Stata Code Example: 
  •         // Example boxplot in Stata
        sysuse auto, clear
        graph box price, over(foreign)
### Calculating Variation and Degrees of Freedom 1. **Sum of Squares Between (SSB):** Variation between groups. 2. **Sum of Squares Within (SSW):** Variation within groups. 3. **Total Sum of Squares (SST):** Total variation. - **Degrees of Freedom:** - df_between = k - 1 (where k is the number of groups) - df_within = N - k (where N is the total sample size) ### The F Statistic and P-Value The F statistic is calculated using the ratio of mean squares: $$ F = \frac{MSB}{MSW} $$ - MSB: Mean Square Between - MSW: Mean Square Within The p-value is derived from the F distribution, given the degrees of freedom. The F-distribution is a continuous probability distribution that arises frequently as the null distribution of test statistics, particularly in analysis of variance (ANOVA). It is characterized by two parameters: the degrees of freedom of the numerator (df_between) and the degrees of freedom of the denominator (df_within). ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} source('../ShinyApps/anova_F_ratio_app.R') ``` ::: ### Hands-on Example: Interpreting Results download ex. 1 data (CSV)
JMP Instructions:
  • Go to Analyze > Fit Y by X.
  • Select the categorical variable as the x-axis and continuous variable as the y-axis.
  • Click OK.
  • Click the red triangle and choose Means/ANOVA to view the results.
R Code Example: 
  •         # Example ANOVA in R
        model <- aov(stress ~ group, data = data)
        summary(model)
Python Code Example: 
  •         # Example ANOVA in Python
        import statsmodels.api as sm
        from statsmodels.formula.api import ols

        # ANOVA model
        model = ols('stress ~ group', data=data).fit()
        anova_table = sm.stats.anova_lm(model, typ=2)
        print(anova_table)
SPSS Instructions:
  • Go to Analyze > Compare Means > One-Way ANOVA.
  • Select the categorical variable as the factor and continuous variable as the dependent list.
  • Click Post Hoc, choose Tukey, and click Continue.
  • Click OK to view the results.
Stata Code Example: 
  •         // Example ANOVA in Stata
        oneway stress group, bonferroni
### Post-hoc Analysis After finding a significant F-statistic, post-hoc analysis helps determine which groups differ.
JMP Instructions:
  • Click the red triangle next to your ANOVA results.
  • Select Tukey HSD under Compare Means.
R Code Example: 
  •         # Tukey HSD in R
        tukey <- TukeyHSD(model)
        print(tukey)
Python Code Example: 
  •         # Tukey HSD in Python
        from statsmodels.stats.multicomp import pairwise_tukeyhsd

        # Tukey HSD
        tukey = pairwise_tukeyhsd(data['stress'], data['group'])
        print(tukey)
SPSS Instructions:
  • Go to Analyze > Compare Means > One-Way ANOVA.
  • Click Post Hoc, choose Tukey, and click Continue.
  • Click OK to view the results.
Stata Code Example: 
  •         // Tukey HSD in Stata
        oneway stress group, bonferroni
